newsitem.title: USA: NAR sees record resale rate for U.S. homes in 1996.
newsitem.headline: NAR sees record resale rate for U.S. homes in 1996.

text.p: The National Association of Realtors on Monday predicted a record resale rate for U.S. homes in 1996.
"NAR expects existing-home sales to total 4.09 million units for 1996, and set a new resale record that tops the previous high of 3.99 million units recorded in 1978," the group said in a statement.
The NAR earlier reported that sales of existing U.S. homes rose 1.8 percent in November to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.04 million units from 3.97 million units in October.
Russell Booth, the group's president, said in a statement that strong consumer confidence has helped to bolster housing activity throughout the nation.
In a briefing with reporters, NAR Chief Economist John Tuccillo predicted that in 1997, the West would continue to be a strong region for existing home sales.
He said space constraints might limit some of the growth in some western cities that have been growing rapidly recently. However, he said the California housing market will continue its rebound.
Overall, he said, "The West will remain strong."
Of all the regions in the country, he said the market in the Northeast would probably experience the slowest growth.
"Generally, what you will see (in the Northeast) is positive growth but not as positive as the rest of the country," Tuccillo said.
